items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

River levels in this area have now fallen below levels of concern. The forecast is largely dry for the coming days and no further flooding is currently expected. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: River levels in this area have now fallen below levels of concern. The forecast is largely dry for the coming days and no further flooding is currently expected. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

River levels are high but steady at the Cae Howel river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Llanymynech peaked at 4.5m Sunday morning, Predicted peaks:-  Cae Howel 4.00m to 4.25m Monday evening 22/09/25.   
No further rainfall is forecast for the next couple of days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 9am Tuesday 23/09/25, or as the situation changes.

We are removing this alert as river levels in the Upper River Aire Catchment have fallen following the heavy rain over the weekend. No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days. Please continue to take care around any standing water on low-lying land and roads.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: Levels have peaked on the River Ouse in York. Levels will remain high but are slowly falling. Flooding is affecting riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. The forecast is largely dry for the coming days, and we expect levels to fall slowly throughout the rest of today, Tuesday 23/09/25. This message will be updated by 07:30PM on 23/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Crew Green river gauge.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. River Severn bankfull at White Abbey. Crew Green peaked at 5.48m early Monday morning, Montford peaked at 4.46m Monday morning. Predicted Peaks:-  Welshbridge 2.2m to 2.5m Monday afternoon 22/09/2025, Buildwas 3.1m to 3.5m Tuesday morning 23/09/2025, Bridgnorth 2.5m to 3.0m on Tuesday afternoon 23/09/2025.   
No further rainfall is forecast for the next couple of days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 9am Tuesday 23/09/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at the Showground and The Quarry, Shrewsbury
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels have peaked, but still pose a flood risk.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land.  No further rainfall is forecast for the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.
Please avoid contact with flood water.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: River and lake levels remain high which may lead to flooding of land and road. Areas most at risk include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. No rainfall is expected today Monday 22/09/2025 and tomorrow Tuesday 23/09/2025. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM tomorrow Tuesday 23/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River and lake levels remain high. Flooding is affecting locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. No rainfall is expected today Monday 22/09/2025 and tomorrow Tuesday 23/09/2025. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM tomorrow Tuesday 23/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: The situation is improving and river levels have fallen below levels of concern. We continue to monitor the forecast and we will re-issue this message If needed. Please continue to exercise care.

Although Lake levels have fallen overnight and are continuing to fall, they remain above the Flood Warning threshold and are continuing to cause flooding. Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. We will continue to monitor rainfall, river, and lake levels. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water, and avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. No rainfall is expected today Monday 22/09/2025 and tomorrow Tuesday 23/09/2025. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM tomorrow Tuesday 23/09/2025, or as the situation changes.
